Question Text: Which of the following are examples of control plane operations? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Computing a shortest path routing tree.
b. Determining that a user's MAC address is authentic before allowing it to send traffic on the network.
c. Rate-limiting traffic so that the overall sending rate does not exceed a certain throughput.
d. Load balancing traffic across two output ports based on the hash of each packet's source IP address.
e. Determining the forwarding path that satisfies an access control policy.
LLM Explanation: Control plane operations involve making decisions about how to handle network traffic. Computing shortest path routing trees (a), authenticating MAC addresses before allowing traffic (b), and determining forwarding paths based on access control policies (e) are all examples of control plane decision making. Rate-limiting traffic (c) and load balancing across ports (d) are data plane operations that enforce the decisions made by the control plane.

Question Text: What could be the operational steps behind the AT&T's IRSCP (a commercial version of the Routing Control Platform) for detecting malicious traffic? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The controller sees all traffic passing through the network, detects an attack, and installs a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where the attack traffic is originating.
b. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to install a null route to drop traffic at the entry point where attack traffic is originating.
c. A victim end host sends an alert to an on-path firewall about the source and nature of an attack, at which point the firewall installs a null route to drop the traffic at the entry point where the attack is originating.
d. The end host changes its IP address so that it is no longer the target of the attack traffic.
e. A measurement system detects an attack, identifies the entry point of the attack, and instructs a controller to re-route traffic through a deep-packet inspection device.
LLM Explanation: The correct steps for AT&T's IRSCP in detecting and mitigating malicious traffic are:b) A measurement system detects the attack, identifies the entry point, and instructs the controller to install a null route at that entry point to drop the attack traffic. This allows the attack to be stopped at the source.  e) Alternatively, the measurement system can instruct the controller to re-route the traffic through a deep packet inspection device for further analysis and filtering of malicious packets. This allows more granular control than a blanket null route.The other options are incorrect because:a) The controller does not see all traffic and detect attacks itself. It relies on the measurement system. c) The end host/victim does not send alerts to an on-path firewall. The detection is done by a separate measurement system.d) Changing the end host IP does not stop the attack traffic from entering and traversing the network.

Question Text: What are some example network management applications that become easier with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved interdomain routing security.
b. Customer-controlled egress selection.
c. Improved logging capabilities.
d. Forecasting of network capacity.
e. Planned maintenance of an edge router.
LLM Explanation: With the separation of control and data planes in SDN, several network management tasks become easier:b. Customers can have more control over egress traffic from their networks by programming the control plane. c. Centralized control allows for improved logging and monitoring of the entire network.d. The global network view enables better capacity planning and forecasting.e. Planned maintenance of individual network elements like an edge router is easier when the control plane can route around it.However, interdomain routing security (a) is not directly made easier by control/data plane separation.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black', 'Software Defined Networking (SDN): Anatomy of OpenFlow by Doug Marschke et al.', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/sdn-definition/']

Question Text: What are some of the motivations for using Layer-2 forwarding in a data center? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Easier configuration/administration, since there is no need to number hosts or configure subnets.
b. Better security properties.
c. Better load balancing properties.
d. Ability to use existing routing protocols to establish paths between hosts.
e. Better scaling properties.
LLM Explanation: Layer-2 forwarding in a data center is motivated by easier configuration and administration, as well as better scaling properties. With Layer-2 forwarding, there is no need to assign IP addresses to hosts or configure subnets, simplifying network setup and management (a). Layer-2 forwarding also allows the network to scale better, as the number of forwarding table entries is limited by the number of MAC addresses rather than IP addresses (e). The other options - better security (b), load balancing (c), and using existing routing protocols (d) - are not key motivations for Layer-2 forwarding in data centers.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networking (SDN) Foundations: A Comprehensive Approach to SDN by Khosrow Vahdatpour and Fei Xu, Chapter 3: Data Center Networking', 'Data Center Fundamentals by Mauricio Arregoces and Maurizio Portolani, Chapter 2: Data Center Design Overview']

Question Text: How does the separation of the control and data plane make networking in data centers easier?
Choices:
a. A network controller can permit the renumbering of end hosts to have topology-dependent Layer 2 MAC addresses.
b. Virtual machines can be migrated within the network without renumbering entire portions of the network or re-assigning network services to different IP addresses.
c. All routes can be controlled and monitored from a central point of control.
d. The control plane allows traffic to be forwarded using Layer 2 addresses, thus allowing automatic load balance across the topology.
e. The separation allows fewer switches to be used in the data center topology, thus lowering costs.
LLM Explanation: The separation of control and data planes in software-defined networking (SDN) enables easier management of data center networks in two key ways:1) It allows virtual machines to be migrated within the network without the need to renumber network segments or re-assign services to different IP addresses. The control plane can dynamically update forwarding rules as VMs move.2) A centralized SDN controller provides a single point of control to manage routing across the entire network. This enables easier configuration, monitoring and troubleshooting compared to distributed control planes.The other options are incorrect: a) SDN does not require or depend on topology-based MAC addressingd) The data plane still forwards based on IP, not L2e) SDN is independent of the number of physical switches used

Question Text: What are some examples of problems that can arise from consistency problems in the control plane, where a network has multiple controller replicas?
Choices:
a. Incorrect security policies.
b. Inability to respond to link failures.
c. Incorrect operation when one controller fails.
d. Forwarding loops.
e. A flood of traffic at the controller.
LLM Explanation: Consistency problems between multiple controller replicas in the control plane of a software-defined network can lead to several issues:a. Incorrect security policies may be applied if the controllers have inconsistent views of the defined policies.  b. The network may be unable to properly respond to link failures if the controllers have inconsistent topology information.c. If one controller fails, the remaining controllers may operate incorrectly if they don't have a consistent, up-to-date view of network state.d. Forwarding loops can occur if the controllers install inconsistent forwarding rules in the data plane switches.While a flood of controller traffic could be an issue in SDN, it's not a direct consequence of control plane inconsistency.

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with inconsistency across controller replicas? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Having multiple controllers install forwarding table entries on the same router and resolving the conflict on the router itself.
b. Using different controllers for independent parts of the network.
c. Running a consistency protocol across controller replicas.
d. Keeping a "hot spare" replica that has a complete view of the network state.
e. Only keeping a subset of the network state in memory at any time.
LLM Explanation: To cope with inconsistency across controller replicas in SDN, some viable approaches are:b) Using different controllers for independent network segments to avoid conflicts. c) Running a consistency protocol to synchronize state across controller replicas.d) Maintaining a hot standby replica with a full copy of the network state to take over if the primary fails.Having multiple controllers program the same router (a) can lead to conflicts. Only keeping a partial network state (e) limits the controller's ability to make optimal decisions.
URLs: ['Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey (Kreutz et al., 2015)', 'Onix: A Distributed Control Platform for Large-scale Production Networks (Koponen et al., 2010)', 'Consistency in Software Defined Networks (Beheshti and Zhang, 2012)']

Question Text: What are some approaches to coping with scalability challenges associated with control and data plane separation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane to reduce traffic at the controller.
b. Running multiple controllers, and having each controller only manage a part of the network.
c. Sending all traffic through the controller to minimize forwarding decisions that the routers and switches must make.
d. Eliminating redundant data structures.
e. Only performing control-plane operations for a limited set of network operations.
LLM Explanation: There are several approaches to address the scalability challenges that arise from separating the control and data planes in SDN:a. Caching forwarding decisions in the data plane can reduce the amount of traffic the controller needs to handle for repeated or similar flows.  b. Distributing the control across multiple controllers, each managing a portion of the network, can improve scalability compared to a single centralized controller.d. Eliminating redundant data structures helps optimize the control plane by reducing unnecessary overhead.e. Limiting the control plane to only essential network operations minimizes the load on the controller.However, sending all traffic through the controller (c) would significantly increase the load on the controller and exacerbate scalability issues, so this is not a viable approach.
URLs: ['Kreutz, D., Ramos, F., Verissimo, P., Rothenberg, C. E., Azodolmolky, S., & Uhlig, S. (2015). Software-defined networking: A comprehensive survey. Proceedings of the IEEE, 103(1), 14-76.', 'Yeganeh, S. H., Tootoonchian, A., & Ganjali, Y. (2013, August). On scalability of software-defined networking. IEEE Communications Magazine, 51(2), 136-141.', 'Karakus, M., & Durresi, A. (2017). A survey: Control plane scalability issues and approaches in software-defined networking (SDN). Computer Networks, 112, 279-293.']

Question Text: Which property guarantees that each RCP replica continues to install correct forwarding state in the network data plane, even in the case of a partition in the data plane?
Choices:
a. The controller cannot see many of the routers in the network anyway, so there is no way for it to install incorrect routing state in the routers that it is not connected to.
b. Running the network from a single high-level control plane guarantees that network partitions and loops never occur in the first place.
c. Each controller has a complete view of the portion of the network that it is controlling, and therefore can guarantee consistent routing within that partition.
d. The controllers are partitioned from the network routers, and the routers will fall back to running a distributed routing protocol.
LLM Explanation: In the event of a network partition, each controller maintains a complete view of the portion of the network it controls. This allows the controller to guarantee consistent routing within its partition, even if it loses visibility of the rest of the network. The controller can continue to install correct forwarding state in the routers it manages.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networking (SDN) Fundamentals, Cisco Press, Chapter 6: Understanding SDN Control Plane Architectures and Controllers', 'https://www.opennetworking.org/images/stories/downloads/sdn-resources/technical-reports/TR-521_SDN_Architecture_issue_1.1.pdf']
